It’s entirely made up of pantry staples. The pickling liquid is just a mix of water, salt, sugar, and vinegar—we’ve opted for apple cider, but white wine vinegar, red wine vinegar, sherry vinegar, or rice wine vinegar would all be fine. After letting your quick-pickled red onions sit for at least an hour to soften and marinate, drain them, and then put them to good use brightening up a juicy pile of ribs, sub them into your favorite breakfast sandwich, or scatter them atop a lunchtime grain bowl. They might be simple to make, but these pickled red onions have layers.Editor’s note: This recipe was originally published on May 15, 2012.IngredientsMakes about ½ cup Servings½cups apple cider vinegar1tablespoon sugar1½teaspoons kosher salt1red onion, thinly slicedPreparationWhisk first 3 ingredients and 1 cup water in a small bowl until sugar and salt dissolve. Place onion in a jar; pour vinegar mixture over. Let sit at room temperature for 1 hour. DO AHEAD: Can be made 2 weeks ahead. Cover and chill. Drain onions before using.Nutrition Per Serving7 Servings 1 serving contains:  Calories (kcal) 10  Fat (g) 0  Saturated Fat (g) 0  Cholesterol (mg)  0  Carbohydrates (g) 3  Dietary Fiber (g) 0  Total Sugars (g) 2  Protein (g) 0  Sodium (mg) 280 How would you rate Quick Pickled Onions?Leave a ReviewTell us what you thinkReviews (28)Back to TopTriangleDefinitely missing the water part! 1/2 cup of apple cider barely covers a whole onion. Made exactly as instructed (including water) One question, do I store IN the liquid, or remove and store separate from the “pickling” liquid?? I want them to last so we can enjoy them!!Ellen McKeeFalmouth, Maine11/30/2021One cup of water is an ingredient.Anonymous11/25/2021Just right for a quick topping.  And as long as you read through the ONE step, you know to add all the ingredients to one cup of water. Lasts about a week in the fridge. Have made it as is, and with subbing about 1/4 of the kosher salt with brining salt (I.e. Prague pink salt) just to see if the flavors change - both goodJen10/30/2021I made this with 4 lb. of skinless boneless breast chicken. I cooked on low for 3.5 hours and followed the recipe except reduced the salt to one tablespoon. It turned out great! The best slow cooking chicken recipe I’ve ever tried. It takes a little longer to put together than other slow cooker recipes due to all the juicing that has to occur, but it is well worth it. You end up wit moist, flavorful chicken; it’s perfect for feeding a crowd, tacos, burritos, salads, etc. AnonymousSan Diego9/18/2021I usually have some of these in the fridge.
